pageContext.claim: “We banned people from China coming in, and they said, ‘Oh, but you did allow people.’ Yeah, they were American citizens, and they were allowed in under very, very strict rules and regulations and quarantines and everything else. But we banned people. And a number of our leading doctors said that would've -- that saved hundreds of thousands of lives. And that was in January. And I remember being in a room with, I think, 21 people, and I was the only one that wanted to do that. Nobody else wanted to do it. They thought it was -- they thought it was crazy.”
pageContext.analysis: Trump is giving a false account of the decision-making process that led to his Jan. 31 ban on foreign travelers from China. Although Anthony Fauci and other public health advisers initially opposed the travel restrictions, they ended up endorsing them before Trump. At a news briefing Feb. 7, Alex Azar, the secretary of health and human services, said the travel restrictions “were the uniform recommendation of the career public health officials here at HHS,” specifically naming Fauci and Robert Redfield, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. “This was their considered recommendation, which I and the president adopted,” Azar said.
